title: Can a Christian lose his or her salvation and end up in hell? - Quora

response.answer_text: As someone stated in a comment below that depends on who does the saving. What God/Christ has accomplished cannot be undone by human efforts or anything in all creation. If we go to hell then we were not truly saved and will be cut off and cast into the fire. If we think that our salvation is dependent upon our works or secured in our abilities then we are denying the power of what was accomplished on the cross. Many people hear the word of God preached, and many call themselves Christians but that doesn’t make one saved. Jesus said “you know the tree by the fruit it bears”. Anyone can “act” like a Christian and appear to be one in the eyes of the world, but they cannot fool God. Their fruit is evidence of whether or not they are saved. Salvation is complete in Christ…by way of sanctification. We are not instantly made like Him…there is a growth process. Those whom He chose will be the ones to avoid His wrath. Think about the wheat and tares…if you’ve ever seen them they look very very similar, almost identical until they’ve matured. Jesus knows who is saved and who is not…those who are will never lose their salvation. This is a question which cannot be truly answered until after death. There are many discussion. People will quote verses to support their arguments without going to the original language and the intended audiences understanding. Or philosophize on the interpretations. You can read extensively and still come to no conclusion because all arguments are infiltrated by mans limited understanding. There is a speaker, John Piper, who, though a reformist and a Calavanist has an interesting view on this; it almost falls under the TULIP implications. He poses the question: ‘If you lose your salvation, were you ever saved in the first place?’ This is a scary thing to consider and the reason it is possible is because of the iterative drift away from strict doctrine to levels of societal doctrine. We tend to be more about feelings than convictions. More into tangibles that ethereal. This means we can be caught up in the hype and not be saved. Or, still caught up in the hype and actually be saved. (Hence my first sentence.) So, how do you tell. The benchmark is always the example of Christ and the early church - as much as it can be. Almost 90% can be applied to the social setting of today. There are at least two things at play here. The first is the reference in scripture to ‘you will know them by their works’. Be careful not to hear what I am not saying. Salvation is not through works but, if saved, you will perform works driven by Christ at a cost to you. The second which comes to mind is your change in being. According to scripture you are a new creation. All of your sins past, present and future have need washed away. This does not mean you will not stumble, sin, or make mistakes. However, you natural inclination will be to clean up your life - subliminally. You will find you no longer do certain things. Your reading of the Bible will take on a different meaning, it will become clearer - if you are not seeking scripture that could be a negative sign. Your friends will notice a difference and your circle of friends will change. There are others but these are the main ones which come to mind. You will hear arguments from people who claim that who ‘Christ has called to himself not one man can pull away’. Notice ‘has called’ which falls under TULIP, and ‘no man’ - even if this read as ‘no one’ the argument would still stand. That is God can release you. He gave you free will so, even if he called you, it is possible, through free will, to reject your salvation. Be warned though, this is not a status you can change readily. What is more, you will not be aware you are doing it until it is too late. This is one reason to ensure you keeep in the body of Christ. Anyway, enough. I could write a book but I am fairly stupid so accept these comments as someone who has walked on both sides. Alan

Christendom is split on that question. There is a very strong belief in the once-saved-always-saved doctrine among evangelical/fundamentalist denominations. Often these are churches where a person must have reached the “age of accountability” and have consciously felt God’s call to be baptised as a Christian. In essence, a conscious conversion to Christianity is always required. Other Christian faiths rely on the teaching that by your works you will be known, with the understanding that God’s Grace is overriding. For churches with infant baptism and later confirmation in the faith, the absence of a clear personal decision and declaration may explain the tentativeness. On such questions wars were fought not too many hundred years ago.

In the first place, you are called to God by the Holy Spirit, and granted the faith to accept. Secondly, God's plan of redemption is complete, ‘no assembly required'. The ‘work' of salvation was God planned and God completed. You cannot ‘undo' what you didn't accomplish.
